info.game_comments: Game data retrieved from an alternate archive.

(1, 1).clue: As a result of the French defeat at the Battle of Dien Bien Phu in 1954, this country was divided at the 17th parallel

(2, 1).clue: The title character of this Beatles song is "wearing the face that she keeps in a jar by the door"

(4, 1).clue: The Rainbow variety of this fish is popularly served "amandine"

(5, 1).clue: Its name is from the French for "lion's tooth"

(6, 1).clue: In a Robert Louis Stevenson novel, a drug turns this man into a monster

(1, 2).clue: In 452 this "Scourge of God" invaded northern Italy, but disease & famine forced his troops to withdraw

(2, 2).clue: For most of the '70s, Elton John collaborated with this lyricist on songs like "Your Song"

(3, 2).clue: On January 8 the state of Louisiana commemorates this battle of the War of 1812

(4, 2).clue: At Starbucks you'll find a variety of these Scottish quick breads to go with your coffee

(5, 2).clue: In a song it was "Crimson & "this weed, "over & over"

(6, 2).clue: With 6,more U.S. Presidents were born with this first name than any other

(1, 3).clue: In 1948 he was elected President of China, but was driven from the mainland to Taiwan the next year

(2, 3).clue: She stayed at No. 1 for 8 weeks in 1993 with "Dreamlover"

(3, 3).clue: Cuba's National Revolutionary Festival in late July commemorates his 26th of July movement founded in 1953

(4, 3).clue: Traditionally, inside your chicken cordon bleu you'll find melted cheese & a thin slice of this meat

(5, 3).clue: It's everywhere! Even in Kentucky's nickname

(2, 4).clue: In 1978 Barbra Streisand & Neil Diamond had a No. 1 hit with this duet

(4, 4).clue: Around St. Patrick's Day, many McDonald's still serve up the cool minty green drink called this

(5, 4).clue: This garden weed may be plain, hemp or stinging

(6, 4).clue: The port city of Aqaba is this nation's only link to the sea

(2, 5).clue: She made her Top 40 debut with 1972's "You Turn Me On, I'm a Radio"

(3, 5).clue: apan's Sanno Festival on April 15 honors Sanno, this religion's mountain god

(4, 5).clue: Alliterative name for the classic French dish consisting of meat braised in red wine with onions & mushrooms

(5, 5).clue: It got its name in the old West from its ability to drive sheep & horses crazy

(6, 5).clue: It refers to the geographic area a court has power over or to the types of cases it can hear

(1, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew presents from Venice) We're at the place where this explorer lived.It's known as del Milione,because Venetians thought he told a million lies

(2, 1).clue: Frances Gumm took her new last name from writer Robert Garland & this first name from a Hoagy Carmichael song

(3, 1).clue: A 7-mile-high peak in the mountain range called Maxwell is the highest feature on this planet, Earth's twin

(4, 1).clue: He exposed questionable design practices in the auto industry in "Unsafe at Any Speed"

(5, 1).clue: This love story by Robert James Waller spent more than 3 years on the bestseller list

(6, 1).clue: Using a slang superlative, Leroy Brown is described as this "man in the whole damn town"

(1, 2).clue: On a Halloween night in the 1750s, this seducer made a daring escape from a cell beneath the Doge's Palace

(2, 2).clue: Born Roy Scherer, he's the movie star seen here

(5, 2).clue: Failed poet Von Humboldt Fleisher is the title character in this Saul Bellow novel

(6, 2).clue: The superlative of the word "old" can start with this letter instead of o

(1, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew presents from Venice.)  This big waterway serves as the main street of Venice. The Venetians call it the Canalazzo, but we call it this

(2, 3).clue: In 1988 this actress, born Margarita Ibrahimoff, married Tom Hanks, born Tom Hanks

(5, 3).clue: His "Postman Always Rings Twice", "Double Indemnity" & "Mildred Pierce" were all made into movies

(6, 3).clue: It's the superlative of "little", as in the proverb This "said, soonest mended"

(6, 4).clue: Superlative in a famous nickname of the NYPD

(0, 0).clue: While serving in the '60s & '70s as this city's last "censor", Richard J. Sinnott banned fewer than 10 things
